{{Year nav topic5|1533|literature}} This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1533'''.
==Events== *October – The censors of the [[Collège de Sorbonne]] stigmatize [[François Rabelais]]' ''[[Gargantua and Pantagruel|Pantagruel]]'' as obscene. *French poet [[Maurice Sceve]] announces that he has found the tomb of "Laura", the woman who is the subject of so many poems by [[Petrarch]], at the church of Santa Croce in [[Avignon]], further strengthening French interest in the Italian poet.<ref>Kennedy, William J. (1999). [https://books.google.com/books?id=j7tj_XxmLwIC&printsec=frontcover#PPA124,M1 "Petrarchan poetics"], in Kennedy, George Alexander, ''et al.'', ''The Cambridge History of Literary Criticism'', '''3''':124. Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|0-521-30008-8}}, {{ISBN|978-0-521-30008-7}}. Retrieved via Google Books 2009-05-27.</ref>
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Henry Cornelius Agrippa]] – ''[[De occulta philosophia libri tres]]'', Books 2 & 3 *[[Antoine Marcourt]] (as Pantople) – ''Le Livre des marchans'' *''Approximate year'' **[[Young Man of Arévalo]] **''Brief Compendium of our Sacred Law and [[Sunnah|Sunna]]'' **''Tafsira''
===Drama=== *[[John Heywood]] **''[[Johan Johan The Husband|The Merry Play between Johan Johan the Husband, Tyb his Wife, and Sir Johan, the Priest]]'' (first published; written [[1520 in literature|1520]]) **''The Mery Play between the Pardoner and the Frere, the Curate and Neybour Pratte'' (first published) **''[[The Play of the Weather|The Play of the Wether, a new and mery interlude of all maner of Wethers]]'' **''The Play of Love''
===Poetry=== {{Main|1533 in poetry}}
==Births== *[[January 2]] – [[Johann Major]], German poet and theologian (died [[1600 in literature|1600]]) *[[January 3]] – [[Jerónimo Bautista Lanuza]], Spanish friar, bishop and homiletic writer (died [[1624 in literature|1624]]) *[[June 6]] – [[Bernardino Baldi]], Italian mathematician, polymath and writer (died [[1617 in literature|1617]]) *[[August 7]] – [[Alonso de Ercilla]], Spanish soldier and poet (died [[1594 in literature|1594]]) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Eknath]], [[Marathi language]] religious poet in the [[Hindu]] tradition of [[India]] (died [[1599 in literature|1599]]) **[[Elazar ben Moshe Azikri]], Jewish [[Kabbalah|kabbalist]], poet and writer (died [[1600 in literature|1600]]) **[[Andrea Rapicio]], Italian poet writing in [[Latin]] (died [[1573 in literature|1573]])<ref name=tmr>{{cite web|url=http://www.mqdq.it/mqdq/poetiditalia/indice.jsp?ordine=crono |title=Tra Medioevo en rinascimento |work=Poeti di Italia in Lingua Latina |accessdate=2009-05-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5h5lnIRZh?url=http://www.mqdq.it/mqdq/poetiditalia/indice.jsp?ordine=crono |archivedate=2009-05-27 |df= }}</ref> **[[Sun Kehong]] (孫克弘), Chinese landscape painter, calligrapher and poet (died [[1611 in literature|1611]]) **(Or 1534) – [[Lucas Janszoon Waghenaer]], Dutch cartographer (died [[1606 in literature|1606]])
==Deaths== *[[July 6]] – [[Ludovico Ariosto]], Italian poet also writing Latin verse (born [[1474 in literature|1474]]) *[[November 6]] or [[November 11|11]] – [[Pieter Gillis]], Flemish humanist, printer and Antwerp city official (born [[1486 in literature|1486]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Giovanni Francesco Pico della Mirandola]], Italian philosopher writing in Latin (born [[1470 in literature|1470]])
==In literature== *The main action of [[Peter Shaffer]]'s drama ''[[The Royal Hunt of the Sun]]'' ([[1964 in literature|1964]]) is set around this year.

[[File:Jan Josef Horemans (II) - Concert in an Interior - 1764.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|''A concert in an Interior'' by [[Jan Josef Horemans the Younger]] of Antwerp, 1764. The women's sack-back gowns and the men's coats over long waistcoats are characteristic of this period.]] '''Fashion in the years 1750–1775''' in European countries and the colonial Americas was characterised by greater abundance, elaboration and intricacy in clothing designs, loved by the [[Rococo]] artistic trends of the period. The French and English styles of fashion were very different from one another. French style was defined by elaborate court dress, colourful and rich in decoration, worn by such iconic fashion figures as [[Marie Antoinette]].
After reaching their maximum size in the 1750s, [[hoop skirt]]s began to reduce in size, but remained being worn with the most formal dresses, and were sometimes replaced with side-hoops, or [[Pannier (clothing)|pannier]]s.<ref name=methoop>"Panniers [British] (1973.65.2)". In Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2000–. http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/1973.65.2 (October 2006)</ref> Hairstyles were equally elaborate, with tall headdresses the distinctive fashion of the 1770s. For men, [[waistcoat]]s and [[breeches]] of previous decades continued to be fashionable.
English style was defined by simple practical garments, made of inexpensive and durable fabrics, catering to a leisurely outdoor lifestyle.<ref name="Ribeiro, Aileen 1820">Ribeiro, Aileen: ''The Art of Dress: Fashion in England and France 1750–1820'', Yale University Press, 1995, {{ISBN|0300062877}}</ref> These lifestyles were also portrayed through the differences in portraiture. The French preferred indoor scenes where they could demonstrate their affinity for luxury in dress and lifestyle. The English, on the other hand, were more "egalitarian" in tastes, thus their portraits tended to depict the sitter in outdoor scenes and pastoral attire.<ref>Ribeiro. ''The Art of Dress''. p. 35.</ref>
== Changes in fashion in the period == [[File:1760s Court Dress.JPG|thumb|English or French court dress, {{circa|1760}}, with wide [[pannier (clothing)|panniers]]. Taken at the Fashion Museum in [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], England.]]
=== 1750s === * Women: Court dress included elaborate and intricate styles influenced by Rococo; hoop skirts; panniers;<ref name="methoop"/> corsets; petticoats; stays; conical torso shape with large hips; "standardized courtly bodies and faces" with little individuality<ref>Wahrman, Dror. ''The Making of the Modern Self: Identity and Culture in Eighteenth-century England''. New Haven: Yale UP, 2004. Print.</ref> ** French: Elaborate court dress, colorful, decorative, portraiture inside ** English: Simple and practical, inexpensive durable fabrics, outdoor lifestyle,<ref name="ReferenceA">Ribeiro, Aileen: ''The Art of Dress: Fashion in England and France 1750–1820'', Yale University Press, 1995</ref> portraiture outside * Men: Coat; waistcoat; breeches; large cuffs; more attention on individual pieces of the suit;<ref name="ReferenceA"/> wigs for formal occasions; long and powdered hair
=== 1760s === * Women: New strapless stays cut high at the armpit; {{lang|fr|grand habit de cour}} or "stiff-bodied" gown; riding habit * Men: Frock coat; knee length breeches fitted snugly; full shirt sleeves; original Macaroni<ref>Amelia Rauser, ''Hair, Authenticity, The Self Made Macaroni'' (Johns Hopkins University Press, Fall 2004) p. 101.</ref>
=== 1770s === * Women: {{lang|fr|robe à la française}} or sack-back gown; {{lang|fr|robe à l'anglaise}} or close-bodied gown; the "Brunswick"; tall hair and headdresses * Men: Waistcoats began to shorten; Macaroni imitators<ref>S. West, ''The Darly Macaroni Prints and the Politics of the Private Man'', Duke University Press</ref>
== Women's fashion ==
=== Overview === [[File:Jean-Marc Nattier 003.jpg|right|thumb|[[Princess Henriette of France]] in court dress playing the [[viola de gamba]], {{circa|1750–52}}, by [[Jean-Marc Nattier]]]] [[File:Batoni lady mary fox.jpg|right|thumb|Lady Mary Fox wears a grey silk hooded Brunswick gown with striped ribbon ornaments, 1767]] Women's clothing styles retained the emphasis on a narrow, inverted conical torso, achieved with boned stays, above full skirts. [[Hoop skirt]]s continued to be worn, reaching their largest size in the 1750s, and were sometimes replaced by side-hoops, also called 'false hips', or [[Pannier (clothing)|panniers]].<ref name=methoop/> Court dress had little or no physical comfort with restriction of movement. Full size hoops skirts prevented sitting and reminded those wearing them to stand in the presence of the King. Stays forced a proper standing posture. Garments like these could not be washed often because of the fabrics from which they were made. The [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] produced a backlash against [[sumptuary law]]s which asserted a stagnant social hierarchy. During the Enlightenment, court dress stayed almost the same while outside of court dress, fashion became less extravagant and shifted more towards comfort rather than courtly display.<ref>McNeil, ''The Appearance of Enlightenment''</ref>
=== Gowns === The usual fashion of the years 1750–1775 was a low-necked [[gown]] (usually called a {{lang|fr|robe}}), worn over a petticoat. Most gowns had skirts that opened in front to show the petticoat worn beneath. If the bodice of the gown was open in front, the opening was filled in with a decorative [[stomacher]], pinned to the gown over the laces or to the stays beneath.
Close-fitting sleeves just past the elbow were trimmed with frills or ruffles, and separate under-ruffles referred to as [[engageante]]s in modern terms, of lace or fine linen were [[tack (sewing)|tacked]], to the inside of the gown's sleeves,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fineartlib.info/gallery/p17_sectionid/10/p17_imageid/899|title=Mrs. Richard Skinner :: John Singleton Copley - 4 women's portraits 18th century hall|website=www.fineartlib.info|access-date=2018-03-13}}</ref> or perhaps to the [[chemise|shift or chemise]] sleeves. The neckline was trimmed with a fabric or lace ruffle, or a neckerchief called a "[[fichu]]" could be tucked into the low neckline. Women would also sometimes wear a neckerchief or a more formal lace modesty piece, particularly on low-cut dresses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fashionencyclopedia.com/fashion_costume_culture/European-Culture-18th-Century/Eighteenth-Century-Clothing.html|title=Eighteenth-Century Clothing|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The {{lang|fr|robe à la française}} or [[sack-back gown]] featured back pleats hanging loosely from the neckline. A fitted bodice held the front of the gown closely to the figure.
The {{lang|fr|robe à l'anglaise}} or [[close-bodied gown]] featured back pleats sewn in place to fit closely to the body, and then released into the skirt which would be draped in various ways.
The [[Brunswick (clothing)|Brunswick]] dress was a two-piece costume of German origin consisting of a hip-length jacket with "split sleeves"—flounced elbow-length sleeves and long, tight lower sleeves—and a hood, worn with a matching petticoat. It was popular for traveling.
Court dress, the {{lang|fr|grand habit de cour}} or "stiff-bodied" gown, retained the styles of the 1670s. It featured a low, oval neckline that bared the shoulders, and the heavily boned bodice laced closed in back, unlike the front-opening robe. The elbow-length sleeves were covered with tiers of lace flounces, echoing the full-sleeved chemise worn with the original style.<ref>{{cite book|last=Waugh|first=Norah|title=The Cut of Women's Clothes: 1600–1930|year=1968|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=0878300260|pages=66–67, 69}}</ref>
Front-wrapping thigh-length "shortgowns" or [[bedgown]]s of lightweight printed cotton fabric were fashionable at-home morning wear, worn with petticoats. Over time, bedgowns became the staple upper garment of British and American female working-class street wear.<ref>Baumgarten, ''What Clothes Reveal'', pp. 116–119.</ref>
As in previous periods, the traditional [[riding habit]] consisted of a tailored jacket like a man's coat, worn with a high-necked shirt, a waistcoat, a petticoat, and a hat. Alternatively, the jacket and a false waistcoat-front might be a made as a single garment, and later in the period a simpler riding jacket and petticoat—without waistcoat—could be worn.
=== Underwear === The shift, [[chemise]] (in France), or smock, had a low neckline and elbow-length sleeves which were full early in the period and became increasingly narrow as the century progressed. [[Undergarment|Drawers]] were not worn in this period.
The long-waisted, heavily boned "stays" of the [[1700–1750 in fashion|early 1740s]] with their narrow back, wide front, and shoulder straps gave way by the 1760s to strapless stays which still were cut high at the armpit, to encourage a woman to stand with her shoulders slightly back, a fashionable posture. The fashionable shape was a rather conical torso, with large hips. The waist was not particularly small. Stays were laced snugly, but comfortably. They offered back support for heavy lifting, and poor and middle class women were able to work comfortably in them.
Free-hanging pockets were tied around the waist and were accessed through "pocket slits" in the side-seams of the gown or petticoat.
Woollen or quilted waistcoats were worn over the stays and under the gown for warmth, as were petticoats quilted with wool batting, especially in the cold climates of northern Europe and America. In the 1770s stays began to be produced so they would end higher on a woman's body. Phillip Vicker complained: "For the late importation of Stays which are said to be now most fashionable in London, are produced upwards so high that we can have scarce any view at all of the Ladies Snowy Bosoms..."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://makinghistorynow.com/2016/01/musings-from-the-millinery-revealing-the-truth-about-18th-century-womens-necklines/|title=Musings from the millinery: revealing the truth about 18th-century women's necklines|website=Making History}}</ref>
[[File:Woman's yellow silk shoes 1760s.jpg|thumb|Woman's yellow silk shoe to be worn with shoe buckle, {{circa|1760–65}}]]
=== Shoes === Shoes had high, curved heels—the origin of modern "louis heels"—and were made of fabric or leather, with separate [[shoe buckle]]s.<ref>Tortora & Eubank 1995, p. 272.</ref> These were either shiny metal, usually in silver—sometimes with the metal cut into false stones in the Paris style—or with paste stones, although there were other types.
=== Hairstyles and headgear === By the 1770s extreme hairstyles and [[Wig (hair)|wigs]] had come into fashion. Women wore their hair high upon their heads, in large plumes. To create tall extreme hair, rolls of horse hair, tow, or wool were used to raise up the front of the hair. The front of the hair was then frizzed out, or arranged in roll curls and set horizontally on the head. Women turned their hair up in the back often in a knot. In addition, pomatum and false hair was used to give more height to the hair. Pomatum was paste that women used to stiffen their hair. Pomatum was also used to hold powder, which women put in their hair. The Pomatum was made of many ingredients including hog's grease, tallow, or a mix of beef marrow and oil.<ref>{{cite book|last=Courtais|first=Georgine de|title=Women's hats, headdresses, and hairstyles: with 453 illustrations, medieval to modern|date=2006|publisher=Dover Publications|location=Mineola, N.Y.|isbn=0486448509|page=76}}</ref>{{-}}

Her sleeves end in flounces worn over lace engageantes. Her stomacher is decorated with a vertical row of ribbon bows. # A 1759 portrait of Madame de Pompadour shows her petticoat trimmed with flounces to match her gown. She wears a small lace ruff around her neck. # Elisabeth Freudenrich wears a gown trimmed with silk ribbons. Her hair is dressed high and two curls frame her neck, 1760. # Lady Susan Fox-Strangways's gown is worn with wide, tiered engageantes, 1761. # Queen Charlotte wears an elaborate neck ruffle with a large diamond brooch with her court gown. Her figure shows the full, rounded bust and small waist created by narrow-backed stays, 1761. # In the American colonies Mrs. John Murray wears a simple gown with cuffed sleeves, 1763. # Mrs. Benjamin Pickman, the wife of a wealthy merchant of Salem, Massachusetts, wears a blue silk gown with robings. She carries a parasol, 1763. # Mrs. Epes Sargent II wears a dark blue riding habit and carries a plumed hat, Massachusetts, 1764. # Marie Antoinette at age 15 wears a riding habit with a striped waistcoat. Her hair is tied back and she wears a tricorn hat, France, 1771. # Mrs John Winthrop of Boston, Massachusetts, in the fashionable dress of 1773. Her indoor cap is trimmed with striped and dotted ribbons, and her gown is trimmed with "robings" of ruched fabric—strips of fabric gathered on two sides. A lace fichu fills in her neckline. # Side view of a frock of 1774 shows pleated robings and striped ribbon rosettes.
=== French fashion === <gallery mode="packed" heights="200"> File:Portrait of the Countess of Senozan.jpg|France, 1751 File:Jean-Marc Nattier 003.jpg|France, 1754 File:Nattier - Portrait de la comtesse de Sérent - 1754.jpg|France, 1754 File:Jean-Marc Nattier, Madame Adélaïde de France faisant des nœuds (1756) - 002.jpg|France, 1756 File:Mme Georges Gougenot de Croissy, née Vïrany de Varennes.jpg|France, 1757 File:Nattier, Jean Marc - Marie Adélaïde of France - Louvre INV 6892.jpg|France, 1758 File:François Boucher 017.jpg|France, 1759 File:Madame Sophie de France (1734–1782).jpg|France, 1762 File:Marie-Josèphe by Nivelon.jpg|France, 1764 File:Boucher - Bergeret NGA.jpg|France, 1766 File:Marie Joséphine Buron par David.jpg|France, 1769 File:Louise-Marie de France, dite Madame Louise (1737-1787).jpg|France, 1770 File:Marie Antoinette by L. L. Périn-Salbreux.jpg|France, 1770 File:Marie Therese de Savoie, comtesse d'Artois.jpg|France, 1775 </gallery>
== Men's fashion == [[File:John Hancock painting.jpg|thumb|[[John Hancock]] of Boston wears a coat with a collar, waistcoat, and breeches of deep blue trimmed in gold braid, 1764]] [[File:The Dallas Museum of Art ' Young Man with a Flute', to the artist George Romney, 1760-1770.jpg|thumb|[[George Romney (painter)|George Romney]]'s ''Young Man with a Flute'' wears a gold figured waistcoat under his coat. His breeches have buttons and buckles at the knee, 1760s.]]
=== Overview === Throughout the period, men continued to wear the [[coat (clothing)|coat]], [[waistcoat]] and [[breeches]] of the [[1700–1750 in fashion|previous period]]. However, changes were seen in both the fabric used as well as the cut of these garments. More attention was paid to individual pieces of the suit, and each element underwent stylistic changes.<ref name="Ribeiro, Aileen 1820"/> Under new enthusiasms for outdoor sports and country pursuits, the elaborately [[embroider]]ed silks and velvets characteristic of "full dress" or formal attire earlier in the century gradually gave way to carefully [[tailor]]ed woollen "undress" garments for all occasions except the most formal. This more casual style reflected the dominating image of "nonchalance." The goal was to look as fashionable as possible with seemingly little effort. This was to be the new, predominant mindset of fashion.
=== Coats === The skirts of the coat narrowed from the gored styles of the previous period. Waistcoats extended to mid-thigh to the 1770s and then began to shorten. Waistcoats could be made with or without sleeves.<ref name="Ribeiro, Aileen 1820"/>
As in the previous period, a loose, T-shaped silk, cotton or linen gown called a [[banyan (clothing)|banyan]] was worn at home as a sort of dressing gown over the shirt, waistcoat, and breeches. Men of an intellectual or philosophical bent were painted wearing banyans, with their own hair or a soft cap rather than a wig.<ref>{{cite web|title=Franklin and Friends|accessdate=2006-03-19|url=http://www.npg.si.edu/exh/franklin/rush.htm}}</ref>
A coat with a wide collar called a [[frock coat]], derived from a traditional working-class coat, was worn for hunting and other country pursuits in both Britain and America.<ref name="Ribeiro, Aileen 1820"/>
=== Shirt and stock === [[Shirt]] sleeves were full, gathered at the wrist and dropped shoulder. Full-dress shirts had ruffles of fine fabric or lace, while undress shirts ended in plain wrist bands.<ref name="Ribeiro, Aileen 1820"/>
=== Breeches, shoes, and stockings === Knee-length breeches fitted snugly and had a fall-front opening.
Low-heeled leather [[shoe]]s fastened with [[shoe buckle|buckles]] were worn with silk or woollen [[stocking]]s. [[Boot]]s were worn for riding. The buckles were either polished metal, usually in silver—sometimes with the metal cut into false stones in the Paris style—or with paste stones, although there were other types. These buckles were often quite large and one of the world's largest collections can be seen at [[Kenwood House]].
=== Hairstyles and headgear === Wigs were worn for formal occasions, or the hair was worn long and powdered, brushed back from the forehead and "clubbed" (tied back at the nape of the neck) with a black ribbon. Wigs were generally now short, but long wigs continued to be popular with the older generation. Wigs were made with a lot of white powder.
Wide-brimmed hats turned up on three sides called "cocked hats"—called [[tricorne|tricorns]] in later eras—were worn in mid-century.{{-|left}}
=== The macaroni === {{main|Macaroni (fashion)}} [[File:Philip Dawe, The Macaroni. A Real Character at the Late Masquerade (1773).jpg|thumb|1773 caricature of the exaggerated style of the macaroni]] The trend of the macaroni grew out of the tradition of those who partook of the [[Grand Tour]]. Elite men in the 18th century would travel abroad across Europe, namely Italy, to broaden their cultural depth. These men adopted foreign fashions and tastes and brought them back to England where they interpreted them further.<ref>Amelia Rauser, ''Hair, Authenticity, The Self Made Macaroni'' (Johns Hopkins University Press, Fall 2004) p. 101.</ref> The original macaroni of the 1760s was characterized by elaborate dress consisting of short and tight trousers, large wigs, delicate shoes and small hats.<ref>Rauser 2004, p. 101.</ref> As the general population of English males became exposed to the luxurious appeal of the macaroni trend, they began to adopt and replicate the trends they saw. By the 1770s, any man could appear as if they themselves had been on the Grand Tour-based solely on their outward appearance.
The macaroni and the subsequent imitators were criticized for being [[Androgyny|gender ambiguous]] and [[effeminacy|effeminate]].<ref>S. West, ''The Darly Macaroni Prints and the Politics of the Private Man'', Duke University Press</ref> Frequently, the macaroni fashion trend was the subject of satirical caricatures and pamphlets.<ref>{{cite book|last=Chenoune|first=Farid|title=A History of Men's Fashion|date=1993|publisher=Flammarion|location=Paris|isbn=9782080135360}}</ref> Their large costume like wigs and short coats, which deeply contrasted the masculine British dress of the time, were ridiculed for their frivolity and were said to be threatening the stability of gender difference, thereby undermining the nation's reputation.<ref>Rauser 2004</ref> The question of farce and inauthenticity comes into play as well because by dressing as a macaroni, one claimed the status and the means of an elite who went on the Grand Tour.
Although many mocked the macaroni for their outwardly eccentric characteristics, some celebrated them for their commitment to the demonstration of personal identity. The idea of a unique character was becoming an important concept that spanned many types of media including books and prints as Britain wanted to distinguish itself from France.<ref>West, p. 175.</ref>
=== Men's style gallery === <gallery mode="packed" heights="180px"> File:Man's 3-piece velvet suit c. 1755.jpg|1 – {{circa|1755}} Image:Georg Friedrich Händel 2.jpg|2 – 1756 File:Man's fitted banyan 1750-1760.jpg|3 – 1750–60 Image:Crowle1760s.jpg|4 – 1761 Image:Voiriot DesVoisins.jpg|5 – 1761 Image:Charles Blair (detail of The Honorable Henry Fane (1739–1802) with Inigo Jones and Charles Blair.jpg|6 – {{circa|1762}} Image:Comte d'Angiviller.jpg|7 – {{circa|1763}} File:1stLordWodehouse.jpg|8 – 1764 File:Nathaniel Sparhawk1 John Singleton Copley.jpeg|9 – 1764 Image:David Hume.jpg|10 – 1766 File:Benjamin West portrait of John Grey 1766.jpg|11 – 1766 File:Denis Diderot 111.PNG|12 – 1767 Image:J S Copley - Samuel Adams.jpg|13 – 1772 </gallery> # Man's 3-piece suit has coat, waistcoat and breeches of cut, uncut and voided silk velvet, France, {{circa|1755}}. The waistcoat buttons match the coat buttons, but are smaller. # Portrait of [[George Frideric Handel]] in a dark red coat with deep cuffs worn over a long gold brocade vest or waistcoat. His shirt has full sleeves gathered at the wrists with ruffles, 1756. # Man's fitted double-breasted [[banyan (clothing)|banyan]], an at-home gown or informal coat, made in the Netherlands of Chinese silk, 1750–60. # Suit of 1761 features a dark blue coat and waistcoat with fine embroidery on the edges, deep cuffs, and pocket flaps. Hair is tied back but not powdered. The waistcoat reaches to mid-thigh. # M. Gilbert DesVoisins, Councillor of State in Ordinary wears a shirt with front and wrist ruffles of fine lace. 1761 # Informal country clothes of 1760–62. The long collared coat without cuffs is a "frock". # Comte d'Angiviller wears a rose-coloured coat with a fur lining over a flowered white satin waistcoat with gold braid or embroidery. His shirt has a lace frill down the front. French fashion emphasizes rich fabrics over cut and tailoring, {{circa|1763}}. # Portrait of [[John Wodehouse, 1st Baron Wodehouse|Lord Wodehouse]] wearing a deep blue coat, waistcoat and breeches, 1764. # Nathaniel Sparhawk of Maine wears a rose velvet suit with a collarless coat, 1764. # David Hume wears a reddish collarless dress coat and matching waistcoat trimmed with bands of gold. His shirt sleeves are gathered into wrist bands with tiny pleats—visible by his left hand—and have fine lace ruffles, 1766. # John Grey, third son of the Earl of Stamford, wears a brown coat and waistcoat over a linen shirt, 1766. # Denis Diderot wears a [[shot silk]] banyan over his waistcoat and shirt. The shirt fastens with buttons and buttonholes at the neck, details usually hidden by the stock, 1767. # Samuel Adams wears a plain coat with wide revers, a small stand-up collar, deep cuffs, and large pocket flaps. His shirt has small sleeve ruffles and is worn with a narrow stock, 1772.
== Children's fashion == During most of this period, the clothes worn by middle- and upper-class children older than toddlers continued to be similar to the clothes worn by adults, with the exception that girls wore back-fastening bodices and petticoats rather than open-fronted robes. Boys wore dresses until they were [[breeching (boys)|breeched]].
<gallery mode="packed" heights="220px"> File:Caroline Matilda 1754 by Liotard.jpg|1 – 1754 File:Badger attributed Two Children Detail of Boy.jpg|2 – 1755–60 Image:Lowry bateson family detail.jpg|3 – 1762 Image:Georg David Matthieu 001.jpg|4 – 1764 File:John Singleton Copley - A Boy with a Flying Squirrel (Henry Pelham) - Google Art Project.jpg|5 – 1765 Image:John Singleton Copley Young Lady with a Bird and Dog.jpg|6 – 1767 File:Bobrinsky (variation).jpg|7 – {{circa|1770}} File:William Williams 01.jpg|8 – 1770–75 </gallery> # Young girl's costume of 1754. # Boy's dress, {{circa|1755–60}} # Young Irish girls wear back-fastening bodices and sheer, embroidered aprons, 1762. # Prince and Princess von Mecklenberg wear the miniature versions of adult costume that were standard for upper-class children, 1764. # American boy wears a frock with a pink satin lining over a buff-colored waistcoat and a collared shirt with wrist frills, 1765. # An American girl of 1767 wears a pink satin back-fastening gown over a smock and black shoes with low heels. # Young Russian boy in court dress, with powdered hair and miniature sword, {{circa|1770}}. # Boy's suit of the early 1770s is worn with a collared shirt and a floppy bow at the neck.
== Working class clothing == [[File:Hogarths-Servants.jpg|thumb|upright=0.85|Portraits of [[William Hogarth]]'s servants (England, 1750s)]] [[File:John Collet The Elopement detail.jpg|thumb|upright=0.85|A working-class woman wears a short dress or [[bedgown]], a patched and mended petticoat, and neckerchief (England, {{circa|1764}})]] Working-class people in 18th century England and the United States often wore the same garments as fashionable people—shirts, waistcoats, coats and breeches for men, and shifts, petticoats, and dresses or jackets for women—but they owned fewer clothes and what they did own was made of cheaper and sturdier fabrics. Working class men also wore short jackets, and some, especially sailors, wore trousers rather than breeches. [[Smock-frock]]s were a regional style for men, especially shepherds. Country women wore short hooded cloaks, most often red. Both sexes wore handkerchiefs or neckerchiefs.<ref name="Styles">Styles, ''The Dress of the People'', pp. 32–36.</ref><ref name="Reveal">Baumgarten, ''What Clothes Reveal'', pp. 106–127.</ref>
Men's felt hats were worn with the brims flat rather than cocked or turned up. Men and women wore shoes with shoe buckles—when they could afford them. Men who worked with horses wore boots.<ref name="Styles" />

{{Infobox artwork | title=A Sea–Spell'' | painting_alignment = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | image = File:Dante Gabriel Rossetti - A Sea-Spell.jpg | image_upright = 1 | alt = | caption = | artist=[[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]] | catalogue = | completion_date = 1877 | type=[[Oil paint]] on [[canvas]] | material = | subject = | height_metric = 111.5 cm | width_metric = 93 cm | height_imperial = 43 7/8 in | width_imperial = 36 5/8 in | metric_unit = cm <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | imperial_unit = in <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | city = [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]] | museum = [[Harvard Art Museums]] | accession = Gift of [[Grenville L. Winthrop]] | website = {{URL|harvardartmuseums.org/art/230614|}} }} '''''A Sea–Spell''''' is an 1877 [[oil painting]] and accompanying 1869 [[sonnet]] by [[England|English]] artist [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]], depicting a [[siren (mythology)|siren]] playing an instrument to lure sailors. It is currently on display in the [[Harvard Art Museums]] in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]].
==Painting==
===Description=== The painting depicts a [[siren (mythology)|siren]] in human form playing a musical instrument "in a thoughtful reverie",<ref name="Roberts">{{cite journal|last1=Roberts|first1=Helene E.|title=The Dream World of Dante Gabriel Rossetti|journal=Victorian Studies|date=June 1974|volume=17|issue=4|pages=376–377}}</ref> surrounded by [[apple]]s, apple [[blossom]]s, and a [[seagull]].<ref name="Austern">{{cite book |last1=Austern |first=Linda |last2=Naroditskaya |first2= Inna | title=Music of the Sirens | publisher=Indiana University Press |year=2006 | url=https://books.google.fr/books/about/Music_of_the_Sirens.html?hl=fr&id=5IBSGG9YegwC |pages=75–77}}</ref> The instrument being played has been described as a [[harp]]<ref name="Austern"/> and as "somewhat related to the [[psaltery]]";<ref name="Wood">{{cite thesis |last=Wood |first=Lorraine |date=2009 |title=The Language of Music: Paradigms of Performance in Dante Gabriel Rossetti, Vernon Lee, James Joyce, and Virginia Woolf |type=Ph.D. (English) |publisher=The University of Utah |url=https://books.google.fr/books?id=IyPS5sakxjkC&pg=PA49&dq=dante+gabriel+rossetti+sea+spell&hl=fr&sa=X&ved=0CF0Q6AEwCGoVChMIms2ik-nOxwIVQjk-Ch34WQCf#v=onepage&q=sea%20spell&f=false |page=49 |access-date=6 August 2016}}</ref> according to an analysis published in the journal ''Music in Art'', it is an unusually short Japanese [[Koto (instrument)|koto]], a traditional 13-stringed [[zither]]-like instrument.<ref name="Johnson">{{cite journal|last1=Johnson|first1=Henry|title=Dante Gabriel Rossetti and Japan: The Musical Instrument Depicted in "The Blue Bower" and "A Sea Spell"|journal=Music in Art|date=2005|volume=30|issue=1|pages=145–153}}</ref>
Rossetti's brother described the subject as "a Siren, or Sea-Fairy, whose lute summons a sea-bird to listen, and whose song will prove fatal to some fascinated mariner."<ref name="McGann"/>
===Execution=== [[File:Dante Gabriel Rossetti - La viuda romana (Dîs Manibus).jpg|thumb|Rossetti's ''The Roman Widow'' (1874), a companion work to ''A Sea–Spell'']] In 1873, Rossetti made a drawing of a sea-maiden playing an instrument, titled ''[[Siren_(mythology)#List_of_Sirens|Ligeia]] Siren'', as a preliminary study for ''A Sea–Spell''.<ref name="Delphi">{{cite book|author=Dante Gabriel Rossetti|title=Delphi Complete Poetical Works of Dante Gabriel Rossetti (Illustrated)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BPyzAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT760|date=2 June 2014|publisher=Delphi Classics|pages=760–61}}</ref> He had begun work on the painting itself by 18 August 1875.<ref name="Fredeman">{{cite book|author1=Dante Gabriel Rossetti|author2=William Evan Fredeman|title=The Correspondence of Dante Gabriel Rossetti|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a8ciRhA1NPUC&pg=PA638|year=2002|publisher=Boydell & Brewer|isbn=978-1-84384-060-2|pages=619, 638, 645}}</ref> His brother [[William Michael Rossetti]] wrote that Gabriel painted the work, along with another [[half-length figure]] painting called ''[[The Roman Widow]]'', after his patron [[Frederick Richards Leyland]] "suggested" that he was interested in buying several such paintings. Leyland later denied making a commitment to do so.<ref name="Fredeman"/>
The model was [[Alexa Wilding]], one of Rossetti's several muses.<ref name="Fredeman"/> ''A Sea–Spell'' was a companion to ''[[Veronica Veronese]]'', for which Wilding also modeled.<ref name="Spence">{{cite book|last=Spence|first=Cathryn|editor=Jill Berk Jiminez|title=Dictionary of Artists' Models|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ogFYAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA570|date=15 October 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-95914-2|pages=570–|chapter=Wilding, Alexa}}</ref><ref name="Agosta">{{cite journal |title=Animate Images: The Later Poem-Paintings of Dante Gabriel Rossetti |last=Agosta |first=Lucien L. |journal=Texas Studies in Literature and Language |volume=23 |issue=1 |year=1981 |pages=78–101 |publisher=University of Texas Press}}</ref> Rossetti was assisted by an unidentified [[naturalist]] in finding and positioning the [[taxidermy|stuffed]] seagull used in the painting, which led to some delay.<ref name="Fredeman"/>
==Poem== Rossetti wrote a [[sonnet]] in 1869 as a "double" of the painting completed years later, as he did for several other works in the same period.<ref name="McGann">{{cite book|author1=Dante Gabriel Rossetti|author2=Jerome J. McGann|title=Collected Poetry and Prose|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dbthC7tDYC4C&pg=PA396|year=2003|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-09802-0|page=396}}</ref><ref name="Johnston1969">{{cite book|author=Robert DeSales Johnston|title=Dante Gabriel Rossetti|year=1969|publisher=Twayne Publishers|page=105}}</ref> The text of the poem is as follows: <poem> Her lute hangs shadowed in the apple-tree, :While flashing fingers weave the sweet-strung spell :Between its chords; and as the wild notes swell, The sea-bird for those branches leaves the sea. But to what sound her listening ear stoops she? :What netherworld gulf-whispers doth she hear, :In answering echoes from what planisphere, Along the wind, along the estuary?
She sinks into her spell: and when full soon :Her lips move and she soars into her song, :What creatures of the midmost main shall throng In furrowed surf-clouds to the summoning rune: :Till he, the fated mariner, hears her cry, :And up her rock, bare-breasted, comes to die?<ref>Rossetti & McGann 2003, pp. [https://books.google.com/books?id=dbthC7tDYC4C&pg=PA192 192-193]</ref> </poem>
==Critical reception and analysis== [[File:Veronica Veronese DAM.jpg|thumb|''[[Veronica Veronese]]'' (1872), another companion to ''A Sea–Spell'']] [[Jerome McGann]] wrote that the painting is a "failure", caused by Rossetti's excessive intellectualizing of his work; previous critics suggested, to the contrary, that the work is flawed due to Rossetti's "slipshod" execution.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Review: Rethinking Rossetti (review of "Dante Gabriel Rossetti and the Game that Must be Lost", by Jerome McGann)|last=Frith |first=Richard |journal=The Cambridge Quarterly |volume= 32 |issue= 1|year=2003 |pages=81–85}}</ref>
Scholar Helene E. Roberts wrote that the painting is one of a group of depictions of Rossetti's "ideal woman". She wrote that the iconic image of womanhood dominated Rossetti's "dream world", and that the painting is intended to evoke similar reveries in the viewer, citing its musical theme as a prompt for "indolent musing". She argued that, although the combination of daydreaming and womanhood in ''A Sea–Spell'' could be [[pornography|pornographic]], Rossetti encourages more spiritual responses, emphasizing the subject's face and making her exposed arms "masculine, or at best matronly".<ref name="Roberts" />
Lucien Agosta argued that the piece illustrates a theme in Rossetti's work of Art as independent of, and triumphant over, [[Nature]]. He noted that Rossetti, in a letter, had written that the subject's song was a "magic lay" and that the sonnet describes unnatural "netherland gulf-whispers", and that the siren's attraction of a bird to listen to her song inverts the relationship of ''[[Veronica Veronese]]'', in which the musician is inspired by a bird.<ref name="Agosta"/>
==History== The painting was owned by Leyland, who may have acquired it from Rossetti, and sold through [[Christie's]] in 1892. It was owned by [[T. F. Wigley]], David Croal Thomson, and [[William Lever, 2nd Viscount Leverhulme|William Hulme, Viscount Leverhulme]], who sold it in 1926 through Anderson Galleries of [[New York City|New York]]. Anderson Galleries sold it to another New York dealer, Scott & Fowles, from whom lawyer and art collector [[Grenville Lindall Winthrop|Grenville L. Winthrop]] purchased it in 1935. Winthrop donated the work to the [[Fogg Art Museum]] of his ''[[alma mater]]'', [[Harvard University]], in 1939.<ref name="HAM">{{cite web|last1=Harvard Art Museums curatorial staff|title=From the Harvard Art Museums' collections: A Sea-Spell|url=http://www.harvardartmuseums.org/art/230614|accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref>
''A Sea–Spell'' was exhibited in a posthumous Rossetti show at the [[Burlington Fine Arts Club]] of [[London]] in 1883; in the [[Art Gallery of South Australia|National Gallery of South Australia]], on loan from Wigley, in 1899;<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article166447716 |title=Fair and Unfair |newspaper=[[Quiz And The Lantern]] |volume=X, |issue=501 |location=South Australia |date=27 April 1899 |accessdate=16 June 2018 |page=11 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> in a Rossetti-centered exhibition at the [[Spencer Museum of Art|University of Kansas Museum of Art]] in 1958; at the [[National Museum of Western Art]] of [[Tokyo]] in 2002; and as part of many Fogg Art Museum and Harvard Art Museums exhibitions. It is currently on display on the second floor of the Harvard Art Museums.<ref name="HAM" />

Asian Art | formernames = Archives of the Chinese Art Society of America | publisher = [[University of Hawaii Press]] on behalf of the [[Asia Society]] | country = United States | frequency = Annual | history = 1945–present | website = http://www.uhpress.hawaii.edu/journals/asianart/ | link1 = http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/archives_of_asian_art/ | link1-name = Online access at [[Project MUSE]] | ISSN = 0066-6637 | JSTOR = 00666637 }} '''''Archives of Asian Art''''' is an annual [[academic journal]] covering [[the arts]] of South, Southeast, Central, and East Asia. Each issue contains articles by [[scholar]]s of [[art]] and a selection of outstanding works of Asian art acquired by North American [[art museum|museums]] during the previous year.
The journal was established in 1945 as the ''Archives of the Chinese Art Society of America''. It obtained its current title with volume 20 in 1966. The journal is owned by the [[Asia Society]], which in 2007 changed its publisher from [[Brepols]] to the [[University of Hawaii Press]].
Volumes 1–55 (1945–2005) are available on [[JSTOR]]; recent volumes are available on [[Project MUSE]].

revision.text:
The '''Bay Area Reference Center''' (BARC) was a [[Reference librarian|reference]] service serving nine [[Northern California]] [[public library]] systems and headquartered at the [[San Francisco Public Library]]. It was established as an experiment in 1967 by the [[California State Library]] and closed down in 1988, when the funding from the US Federal Government that it relied on was ended. It pioneered the use of networking technologies such as [[teletype]] and [[fax machine]]s in providing reference services to patrons at far-flung, sometimes rural libraries. Its magazine, ''Synergy'', won two [[American Library Association|ALA]] awards.
==Background== Studies of public library services in California had shown that large parts of the state, particularly rural areas, were underserved.<ref name=Wiley176>{{cite book |first=Peter Booth |last=Wiley |title=A Free Library in this City: The Illustrated History of the San Francisco Public Library |location=San Francisco |publisher=Weldon Owen |year=1996 |isbn=9781875137053 |page=176 }}</ref> In response, a 1962 master plan called for the establishment of four levels of library services: local libraries, regional reference centers, tertiary reference centers covering larger regions, and as the fourth and final level, the State Library in [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]]. The Bay Area Reference Center was established in August 1967 as a tertiary center, or "source of last resort",<ref name=Wiley176/> as a collaboration between the San Francisco Public Library and the North Bay Cooperative Library System (NBCLS), a consortium of nine public library systems including 17 libraries in six counties north of San Francisco, with its headquarters in [[Santa Rosa, California|Santa Rosa]]. It was made possible by a federal grant under the 1964 [[Library Services and Construction Act]]; the initial grant was $750,735 for a two-year pilot project.<ref name=Synergy>{{cite journal |first=Richard |last=Coenenberg |title=SYNERGIZING Reference Service in the San Francisco Bay Region |journal=ALA Bulletin |volume=62 |issue=11 |date=December 1968 |pages=1379–84 |jstor=25698028 }}</ref> A corresponding service was set up for Southern California, the [[Southern California Answering Network]] (SCAN).<ref name=Dustin>{{cite book |first=M. J. |last=Dustin |contribution=The MINITEX Reference Service: A Publicly Funded Information Broker |editor1-first=Robin |editor1-last=Kinder |editor2-first=Bill |editor2-last=Katz |editor3=School of Library and Information Science, State University of New York at Albany |title=Information Brokers and Reference Services |location=New York |publisher=Haworth |year=1988 |isbn=9780866567305 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l9LxSiaxAmYC&pg=PA137&lpg=PA137&dq=Bay+Area+Reference+Center+BARC&source=bl&ots=P_BFJW2UkA&sig=Erbv5nGrCAe343XtywsZppf0Ymc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjPn5jwqZHNAhUIyGMKHfUnAcA4ChDoAQgjMAM#v=onepage&q=Bay%20Area%20Reference%20Center%20BARC&f=false |page=137 }}</ref><ref name=Crowley>{{cite book |first=Terence |last=Crowley |contribution=Referred Reference Questions: How Well Are They Answered? |editor1-first=Bill |editor1-last=Katz |editor2-first=Ruth A. |editor2-last=Fraley |title=Evaluation of Reference Services |location=New York |publisher=Haworth |year=1984 |isbn=9780866563772 |pages=83–92 }}</ref>
==Services== Patron questions that could not be answered locally were referred first to one of three secondary reference centers within the system, located at the [[Vallejo Public Library]], the [[Ukiah-Mendocino County Library]], and the [[Santa Rosa-Sonoma County Public Library]]. If still unanswerable, they were sent on via a six-day-a-week teletype link to BARC at the [[San Francisco Main Library]]. Five NBCLS libraries, the San Francisco Main Library and two San Francisco branches, including the downtown business branch, also had fax machines that were sometimes used for delivering information to patrons. BARC had its own director, assistant director, clerical workers, and eight subject specialists, and acquired specialist reference materials to supplement those already available in the San Francisco library system. The staff also researched some questions in person and by phone and fax,<ref name=Synergy/><ref>{{cite book |first=Celeste |last=West |authorlink=Celeste West |contribution=Introduction: ''Revolting Librarians'' Rides Again'' |editor1-first=Toni |editor1-last=Samek |editor2-first=K. R. |editor2-last=Roberto |editor3-first=Moyra |editor3-last=Lang |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KUZE-U_zq4kC&pg=PA226&lpg=PA226&dq=Bay+Area+Reference+Center+BARC&source=bl&ots=NFv9wFVHt0&sig=_CMNx4A3DKNvL7Mtu3eehkQsIHk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjPn5jwqZHNAhUIyGMKHfUnAcA4ChDoAQgfMAE#v=onepage&q=Bay%20Area%20Reference%20Center%20BARC&f=false |title=She Was a Booklegger: Remembering Celeste West |location=Duluth, Minnesota |publisher=Library Juice |orig-year=2003 |year=2010 |isbn=9780980200492 |page=226 }}</ref> and formed relationships with the libraries at the [[University of California, Berkeley]], [[NASA]], the [[Library of Congress]], the [[British Library|British Museum]], and corporations in the region that had specialized libraries.<ref name=Wiley178>Wiley, p. 178.</ref> There were frequent interchanges and staff visits between the NBCLS libraries and BARC.<ref name=Synergy/>
BARC staff conducted biweekly workshops for reference librarians and published bibliographies on topics including the Chinese in California and the San Francisco Public Library's collection on theatrical costumes.<ref name=Synergy/>
===Journals=== Beginning in 1967 BARC published a bibliographic magazine called ''Synergy''. This included controversial topics of the day, such as "the New Left, the New Right, the underground press, feminism, and gay liberation."<ref name=Wiley178/> It twice won the ALA's H. W. Wilson Library Periodical Award,<ref name=Wiley178/><ref name=protest>{{cite journal |first=Edward |last=Swanson | title=Synergy Protest |journal=American Libraries |volume=4 |issue=7 |date=July–August 1973 |page=408 |type=Letter |jstor=25619256 }}</ref> and was so popular its circulation was capped for cost reasons after reaching 2,000, but after its second editor, [[Celeste West]], published an unflattering photograph of [[Richard Nixon]] in 1973, its funding was withdrawn by the state librarian, [[Ethel Crockett]].<ref name=Wiley178/><ref>West, p. 228.</ref> Edward Swanson, president of the Minnesota Library Association, published a protest resolution in the ALA journal,<ref name=protest/> and West's reprimand for unprofessional behavior was withdrawn, but ''Synergy'' was replaced by ''BARC Notes''.<ref name=Wiley178/>
==Closure== BARC closed down after the federal funding on which it depended was ended in 1988.<ref name=Wiley178/>
==Effectiveness== When it closed, BARC served a region populated by 12 million people.<ref name=Wiley178/> In 1978, one analyst saw potential in such pooling of resources to serve a region.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Thomas |last=Childers |title=The Future of Reference and Information Service in the Public Library |journal=The Library Quarterly |volume=48 |issue=4: ''Proceedings of the Thirty-Ninth Annual Conference of the Graduate Library School, April 10-11, 1978. The Public Library: Circumstance and Prospects'' |date=October 1978 |jstor=4307020 |page=465 }}<!-- NOT [[Thomas Childers]] --></ref> In 1984, a comparison of responses to the same genuine patron queries by BARC, the second-level reference center in [[Fresno, California|Fresno]], and a for-profit reference service, Information on Demand, showed that BARC's answers were usually better than the Fresno center's as a result of the depth of its resources, but that none of the three answered all the test questions correctly and quickly.<ref name=Crowley/> The tertiary reference centers were expensive: in 1986 BARC and its Southern Californian counterpart, SCAN, estimated the cost of answering each query at $150, and the California State Library launched a study of costs of the two centers.<ref name=Dustin/>
==People== Richard Coenenberg was the first director of BARC. Assistant Director Gil MacNamee later became director. In addition to West, Peggy Barber, later an ALA staff member, was one of the librarians.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Excellence in Action: 1999 ALA Award Winners |journal=American Libraries |volume=30 |issue=8 |date=September 1999 |page=80 |jstor=25637296 }}</ref>

[[Image:Blocking2.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Crochet samples during blocking. After soaking in hot water these items were shaped and laid to dry on a towel. [[Pin]]s hold some examples in the desired shape.]] [[Image:BlockedLaceScarf.JPG|thumb|knitted scarf during blocking]] In [[knitting]], [[crochet]] and other [[textile arts]], '''blocking''' is a final stage of handmade textile production that adjusts the shape of the finished piece. Not all pieces need blocking; however, blocking is standard for [[lace]] work and is not uncommon in sweaters, socks, and other solid projects. Through [[heat]] and [[moisture]], blocking sets the [[stitch (textile arts)|stitch]]es and standardizes the final dimensions, and may enhance the drape.<ref>Edie Eckman, ''The Crochet Answer Book'', North Adams, Massachusetts: Storey Publishing, 2005, p. 237.</ref> Hand manufacture places natural stresses on fabrics that may result in deviations from its intended shape and size. Blocking is only effective on natural fibres<ref>Debbie Stoller, ''Stitch 'N Bitch Crochet: The Happy Hooker'' New York: Workman Publishing, 2006, p. 89.</ref> but a technique called [[#.22Killing.22|"killing"]] may be used on synthetic fibres to achieve an effect similar to blocking.
The degree of malleability is determined by the type of [[yarn]] used, with [[wool]] providing the most flexibility. For projects that are produced in sections, blocking is normally done prior to final assembly.
==Blocking methods==
[[File:Lace knitting 2.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Unblocked lace stole still on the needles. This item will expand significantly after pinning and blocking.]]Blocking can be done in several different ways. Depending on the method, the crafter may use rustproof [[pin]]s, blocking wires, a steamer, or a [[steam iron]]. A stable flat surface and [[towel]]s are standard. Fibres that tolerate water well may be wet blocked, shaping moist fabric into the desired shape and then allowing it to air dry. Cold blocking uses no heat and less water to achieve the same result by spraying water upon the material instead of immersing the fabric. Steam blocking uses a steamer or steam iron, but without applying direct pressure to the item.<ref>Eckman, p. 238.</ref>
=== Wet blocking ===
Wet blocking is done by saturating a garment in warm water and allowing it to dry. Some items (especially lace) are stretched while wet with the use of pins and/or blocking wires, while others may be gently shaped without stretching.
=== Steam blocking ===
Steam blocking is done by hovering a hot, steaming iron over the fabric. Hovering the iron about 1 or 2 inches above the fabric flattens the stitch, makes it thinner, and allows it to hold its shape better. This is the only method that works for blocking synthetics, like acrylic.
=== Spritz blocking ===
Spritz blocking involves spraying the garment with water. This relaxes the fibres more than steam blocking but less than wet blocking. Most often, a spray bottle is used.
=== "Killing" === It is possible to "set" synthetic fibres through a process known as "killing", wherein the item is pinned in place and carefully steamed to achieve a very slight controlled melt of the fibres. "Killed" fabrics are permanently set and cannot be returned to their original form through washing.

Broel Towers and the [[Leie|Lys river]]]] The '''Broel Towers''' ({{lang-nl|Broeltorens}}) are a classified monument and a [[landmark]] in the Belgian city of [[Kortrijk]]. The towers are known as one of the most important symbols of the city. == History == Although they look identical, the towers were not built at the same time. The Southern tower, also known as the ''Speyetoren'', was built in 1385 to control the traffic on the [[river Lys]]. This tower was part of the fortified fence of the first [[medieval]] castle of the [[Counts of Flanders]]. The Speyentoren was also part of the 12th century rampart, destroyed by Louis XIV in the 17th century.
The Northern tower, known as the ''Ingelborchtoren'' was built in 1415 and was used as an [[Armory (military)|armory]]. Nowadays, the towers are, together with the Artillerytower (''in Dutch: Artillerietoren''), the last remaining parts of the [[medieval]] [[city wall]] around the city. Most of the fortifications in Kortrijk were ordered to be destroyed by [[Vauban]] in 1683, a period in which the French and the Spanish armies repeatedly fought over control of the region. The remaining parts were destroyed in the 18th century and during the world wars. A statue of [[John of Nepomuk]] can be found in the middle of the bridge spanning between the two towers. This statue of the patron saint of the drowned has, ironically, fallen into the river Lys on several occasions due to warfare in the city. The bridge between the two towers was destroyed in both world wars. ==Gallery== File:Kortrijk-Courtrai.jpg|The Broel towers and {{Interlanguage link multi|Broel Bridge|nl|3=Broelbrug}} File:Statue of John of Nepomuk in Kortrijk.jpg|[[John of Nepomuk]] statue on the Broel Bridge File:Kortrijk Broeltorens.jpg|The 'Speytorre' (l.) and the 'Inghelburghtorre' (r.) File:Ingelborchtoren.jpg|The Inghelburghtorre (1415) File:59389 Broeltorens Kortrijk.jpg|The 'Speytorre' or 'Blauwe Toren' (1385) == External links == {{commonscat|Broeltorens}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080602155218/http://www.fortified-places.com/courtrai.html More information on the medieval fortifications around Kortrijk] {{coord|50.829|N|3.265|E|display=title|source:frwiki}} [[Category:History of Kortrijk]] [[Category:Medieval architecture]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Kortrijk]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in West Flanders]] [[Category:Towers in Belgium]]

'''Burning in Water gallery''' is a contemporary art gallery located in Chelsea, New York City.
Artists represented by Burning in Water include [[Valerie Hegarty]], Jessie Krimes, and Borinquen Gallo.
Originally opened as an innovative curatorial project space in 2016, the gallery has since become a primary market gallery.
Past notable exhibitions include Hegarty's ''American Berserk'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://events.umich.edu/event/43941|title=American Berserk exhibition by Valerie Hegarty {{!}} Happening @ Michigan|website=events.umich.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref> Krimes' ''Marking Time in America'', and Gallo's ''Like a Jungle Orchid for a Lovestruck Bee''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/new-york-fall-gallery-show-preview-1005836|title=Here Are 51 New York Gallery Shows That You Need to (Somehow) See This September {{!}} artnet News|date=2017-09-07|work=artnet News|access-date=2017-11-09|language=en-US}}</ref>

{{About-distinguish2|the British artist|his son the writer Damian "Danes" Le Bas}} {{Infobox person | name = Damian Le Bas | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{birth date|1963|01|30}} | birth_place = [[Sheffield]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2017|12|09|1963|01|30}} | death_place = [[Worthing]] | nationality = British | other_names = | occupation = British artist | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Damian Le Bas''' (30 January 1963, [[Sheffield]] – 9 December 2017, [[Worthing]]) was a British artist associated with the [[Outsider art|Outsider Art]] (or "Art Brut") label, as well a leading exponent of the "Roma Revolution" in art.
==Life== Le Bas was of [[Irish traveller|Irish Traveller]] heritage.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/high-profile-stories-of-children-expose-europes-anti-roma-prejudice/article15200641/|title=High-profile stories of children expose Europe’s anti-Roma prejudice|publisher=|accessdate=11 December 2017|via=The Globe and Mail}}</ref> Le Bas attended the [[Royal College of Art]].<ref name="SS_Ob">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2000/oct/29/life1.lifemagazine4|title=Outsider dealing|last=Steward|first=Sue|date=29 October 2000|work=The Observer|accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref>
He lived and worked with his wife, the [[Romani people|Romany]] artist [[Delaine Le Bas]],<ref name="SS_Ob" /> in [[West Sussex]] on the south coast. He was the father of writer [[Damian_Le_Bas_(writer)|Damian Le Bas]].
== Collections == Since 1987 several of Le Bas' pieces are held in the Musgrave-Kinley Collection of works by key Outsider artists, administered by [[Monika Kinley]], until her death in 2014.<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2014/apr/06/monika-kinley|title=Monika Kinley obituary|last=Dempsey|first=Andrew|date=6 April 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/gesellschaft/damian-le-bas-britischer-kuenstler-ueberraschend-gestorben-a-1182758.html|title=Britischer Künstler: Damian Le Bas ist tot|date=11 December 2017|publisher=|accessdate=11 December 2017|via=Spiegel Online}}</ref> His more recent work is found, among others, in the collections of Perpetuum Mobile.
==Exhibitions== He exhibited frequently in the UK and Germany, and his works have been shown at Moderna Museet in Sweden,<ref name="perpetualmobile">{{Cite news|url=http://www.perpetualmobile.org/the-invisible-faces-of-europe-panel-debate-europas-osynliga-ansikten-paneldebatt/?lang=en|title=The Invisible Faces of Europe: Pop-Up Exhibition and Panel Debate - Perpetual Mobile|date=2015-11-30|work=Perpetual Mobile|access-date=2017-12-25|language=en-US}}</ref> in Japan, France, Finland and the United States. He was well-known in Outsider Art circles, and was exhibited as part of a survey-show of [[Art brut|Art Brut]] at Malmö Konsthall in 1991.<ref name="damianlebasartbrut">{{Cite news|url=http://damianlebasartbrut.com/2016/03/09/sarlingar-art-brut-outsider-art-malmo-konsthallas-katalog/|title=SARLINGAR, Art Brut, Outsider Art ( 1991, Malmo konsthallas katalog )|date=2016-03-09|work=Damian Le Bas {{!}} Art Brut|access-date=2017-12-25|language=en-GB}}</ref> He was a participant of the [[Prague Biennale|Prague Biennale 3]].<ref name="praguebiennale">{{cite web|url=http://www.praguebiennale.org/3/eng/|title=PRAGUEBIENNALE3|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140404063523/http://www.praguebiennale.org/3/eng/|archivedate=4 April 2014|deadurl=yes|accessdate=4 August 2014|df=}}</ref>
In later years, the Traveller - Romani - Gypsy experience became a recurrent theme in his work. Le Bas was invited to participate in the 1st Roma Pavilion at the [[Venice Biennale]] in 2007.<ref name="opensocietyfoundations">{{cite web|url=http://www.opensocietyfoundations.org/reports/paradise-lost-first-roma-pavilion-venice-biennale|title=Paradise Lost: The First Roma Pavilion at the Venice Biennale|year=2007|publisher=Open Society Foundations|accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref> He subsequently became a driving force behind the Perpetual Romani-Gypsy Pavilion in Venice in 2009<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.perpetualmobile.org/perpetual-roma-gypsy-pavilion-supporters/?lang=en|title=SUPPORTERS of the PERPETUAL ROMA-GYPSY PAVILION - Perpetual Mobile|date=2009-09-09|work=Perpetual Mobile|access-date=2017-12-25|language=en-US}}</ref> and the co-initiator of the 4th Roma Pavilion which took place in Berlin in 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.perpetualmobile.org/safe-european-home-berlin-2/?lang=en|title=The 4th Roma Pavilion: SAFE EUROPEAN HOME? Berlin - Perpetual Mobile|date=2013-04-21|work=Perpetual Mobile|access-date=2017-12-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
He exhibited frequently in the UK and Germany, and his works have been shown in Japan, France, Finland, Sweden and in the United States. *[[Malmö Konsthall]], Malmö, Scania, Sweden, 1991. A survey-show of [[Art brut|Art Brut]].<ref name="damianlebasartbrut" /> *1st Roma Pavilion at the [[Venice Biennale]], 2007.<ref name="opensocietyfoundations" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.universes-in-universe.de/car/venezia/eng/2007/tour/roma/img-24.htm|title=Damian Le Bas|last=Acton|first=Thomas|publisher=Universes in Universe|accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref> *[[Moderna Museet]], Stockholm, Sweden<ref name="perpetualmobile" /> *[[Prague Biennale|Prague Biennale 3]]<ref name="praguebiennale" />

{{Infobox website |name = Digital blasphemy |logo = |logocaption = |screenshot = |collapsible = |collapsetext = |caption = |url = {{URL|http://digitalblasphemy.com/}} |slogan = |commercial = yes |type = |registration = required for premium content |language = English |content license = |owner = Ryan Bliss |author = |launch date = <!--{{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}}--> |alexa = {{IncreaseNegative}} 160,183 ({{as of|2014|4|1|alt=April 2014}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/digitalblasphemy.com |title= Digitalblasphemy.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2014-04-01 }}</ref><!--Updated monthly by OKBot.--> |revenue = |current status = |footnotes = }} '''Digital Blasphemy''' is a commercial website for [[computer wallpaper]]s designed and created by independent [[Computer-generated imagery]] artist Ryan Bliss, an English and [[Computer Science]] graduate from the [[University of Iowa]]. The name Digital Blasphemy was chosen because of the "Godlike" feeling Bliss experienced when creating worlds through artwork.<ref name="name">{{cite web|url= http://digitalblasphemy.com/faq.shtml#name|title= Digital Blasphemy FAQ | publisher= [[Ryan Bliss]] |accessdate= 2011-08-01 }}</ref>
The site is subscription-based, but a free gallery is available to non-members. Images in the free gallery are rotated regularly with fresh images,<ref name="removed">{{cite web|url=http://digitalblasphemy.com/faq.shtml#removed|title= Digital Blasphemy FAQ | publisher= [[Ryan Bliss]] |accessdate= 2011-08-01 }}</ref> and are presented in various [[Display resolution|screen resolutions]].<ref name="resolutions">{{cite web|url=http://digitalblasphemy.com/faq.shtml#resolutions|title= Digital Blasphemy FAQ|publisher= [[Ryan Bliss]] |accessdate= 2011-08-01 }}</ref> In addition, the free gallery provides multi-monitor samples and mobile device images for Android devices, as well as [[BlackBerry]], [[iPhone]], and [[Palm OS|Palm]]. The member gallery includes all available artwork numbering over 820, not including image alternate forms.<ref name="membership">{{cite web|url=https://secure.digitalblasphemy.com/signup.shtml|title= Digital Blasphemy Membership|publisher= [[Ryan Bliss]] |accessdate= 2014-06-23 }}</ref>
Some images have additional forms and are in a section known as the "Picklejar". This provides, variously, the same images in different colors or presentations, or similar images with removed, added, or changed content or elements. At times, the original image ends up in the Picklejar section and the updated and improved image takes its place in the main gallery.<ref name="picklejar">{{cite web|url=http://digitalblasphemy.com/pj/|title=Digital Blasphemy PickleJar|publisher= [[Ryan Bliss]] |accessdate= 2011-08-01 }}</ref> A way to browse Pickle Jar images was added in June 2014.<ref name="Picklejar List">http://digitalblasphemy.com/picklejar.shtml?i=pickles&mode=list</ref>
==Designs== Typical designs include science fiction and fantasy, space imagery, planetscapes, landscapes, cityscapes, seascapes, underwater scenes, interiors, abstracts, fractals. There are also images depicting seasons and seasonal events, special occasions, and holidays such as Halloween, Christmas, the Fourth of July, Saint Patrick's Day, and Valentine's Day.
Wallpapers come in many display resolutions up to 7680 x 1600, including widescreen and [[multi-monitor]] formats to accommodate various monitor configurations. Only subscribers have access to the highest resolution wallpapers. As of July 2007, many wallpapers were converted to display on mobile devices such as cell phones and tablets, and the first [[1080p]] animated wallpaper was created.<ref>[http://www.digitalblasphemy.com/dbhome.shtml Digital Blasphemy 3d Wallpaper<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Digital Blasphemy wallpapers were used in [[Stardock]]'s weather product, ''[[Natural Desktop|The Natural Desktop]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stardock.com/products/natural/ |title=Natural Desktop - Background based on time of day and time of year |publisher=Stardock |date= |accessdate=2012-07-02}}</ref>
==Reception==
Digital Blasphemy's work has been recommended by [[Lifehacker]],<ref name=Lifehacker>{{cite web|last=Henry|first=Alan|title=Five Best Wallpaper Sites|url=http://lifehacker.com/5876063/five-best-wallpaper-sites|work=Lifehacker|publisher=Gawker Media|accessdate=18 June 2012}}</ref> [[PC World]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Jacobsen|first=Lars|title=Torsdagstippet: Betagende blærede baggrundsbilleder|url=http://www.pcworld.dk/art/8683/torsdagstippet-betagende-blaerede-baggrundsbilleder|work=PC World Denmark|publisher=IDG Danmark A/S|accessdate=18 June 2012}}</ref> [[Yahoo! Internet Life]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Bass|first=Gordon|title=Y-life's 100 Best Sites For 2001: Computing & The Net|work=Yahoo! Internet Life|publisher=Ziff-Davis|accessdate=18 June 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010604040436/http://www.zdnet.com/products/stories/reviews/0,4161,2661322,00.html|archivedate=4 June 2001|url=http://www.zdnet.com/products/stories/reviews/0,4161,2661322,00.html|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> and the G4TV television show [[The Screen Savers]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Actor Jason Lee, Photoshop How To, Multi-Boot System|url=http://www.g4tv.com/screensavers/episodes/2861/actor-jason-lee-photoshop-how-to-multi-boot-system.html|work=G4 TV|publisher=G4 Media, LLC.|accessdate=18 June 2012}}</ref> In January 2012 Digital Blasphemy was named "The Most Popular Wallpaper Website" by readers of Lifehacker.com.<ref>http://lifehacker.com/5876754/most-popular-wallpaper-site-digital-blasphemy</ref>
At its high of popularity, Digital Blasphemy's most popular works included Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of Capricorn.<ref>[http://digitalblasphemy.com/seeall.shtml?y=2001]</ref>

[[tempera]] on [[Panel painting|wood]]; {{convert|52.5|cm|in}} by {{convert|34.5|cm|in}}<ref name="Barberini">{{cite web |url=http://galleriabarberini.beniculturali.it/index.php?it/194/catalogo/catalogo_barberini/610 |title=Storie di Cristo (Natività, Crocifissione, Deposizione nel sepolcro, Discesa al Limbo, Marie al sepolcro, Resurrezione, Giudizio finale) |trans-title=Scenes from the Life of Christ |language=Italian |publisher=[[Ministry of Cultural Heritage and Activities and Tourism (Italy)|Ministero per I beni e le attività culturali]] |accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref>}} Among the paintings attributed to '''Giovanni da Rimini''' (''[[Floruit|fl]]''. 1292–1336) are two [[Panel painting|panels]] from a former '''[[diptych]]''', dated to 1300–1305, of which the left wing is in the collection of the [[National Gallery]], London, and the right that of the [[Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica]], [[Palazzo Barberini]], Rome.<ref name="NG"/><ref name="Barberini"/>
==Giovanni da Rimini== Giovanni, ''pictor'' (painter), later ''maestro'' (master), is known from legal documents to have lived in [[Rimini]] between 1292 and 1336. This Giovanni is thought to be the same as the artist of the inscribed [[crucifix]] ([[:it:Crocifisso di Mercatello sul Metauro|it]]) in San Francesco ([[:it:Museo di San Francesco|it]]), [[Mercatello sul Metauro]], inscribed IOH(ann)ES PICTOR FECIT HOC OPUS / FR(atri) TOBALDI, attesting to its creation by Giovanni the Painter, and dated 1309.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.museodelmetauro.it/?q=it/node/17 |title=Crocifisso Giovanni da Rimini |trans-title=Crucifix by Giovanni da Rimini |publisher=[[:it:Museo di San Francesco|Museo del Metauro]] |accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref><ref name="OUP">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=FtlMAgAAQBAJ&pg=RA2-PA7 |title=The Grove Encyclopedia of Medieval Art and Architecture, Volume 2 |editor=Hourihane, Colum |year=2012 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |pages=7–8 |isbn=978-0195395365}}</ref> Three or four other crucifixes are identified as being by the same artist, influenced by that ([[:it:Crocifisso di Rimini|it]]) of [[Giotto]]: the "Diotallevi” Crucifix ([[:it:Crocifisso (Giovanni da Rimini)|it]]), in the Museo della città, Rimini ([[:it:Museo della città di Rimini|it]]);<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.museicomunalirimini.it/musei/museo_citta/patrimonio_museo_citta/catalogo_mappa_museo_citta/-medievale_moderno_piano1/pagina18.html |title=La Scuola riminese e i dipinti del XIV secolo |trans-title=The Rimini School and paintings of the fourteenth century |language=Italian |publisher=[[Rimini|Comune di Rimini]] |accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> another in San Lorenzo, [[Talamello]];<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.comune.talamello.rn.it/index.php?id=14263 |title=Il Crocefisso di Giovanni da Rimini (1300) |trans-title=Crucifix by Giovanni da Rimini (1300) |language=Italian |publisher=[[Talamello|Comune di Talamello]] |accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> another in San Francesco, [[Sassoferrato]];<ref>{{cite web |url=http://catalogo.fondazionezeri.unibo.it/scheda.jsp?decorator=layout_S2&apply=true&tipo_scheda=OA&id=7629 |title=Giovanni da Rimini, Cristo crocifisso |trans-title=Christ on the Cross, by Giovanni da Rimini |language=Italian |publisher=[[Federico Zeri|Fondazione Federico Zeri]], [[University of Bologna]] |accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> and a fourth sold at [[Sotheby's]] in 2015.<ref name="OUP"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/ecatalogue/2015/so-moretti-n09306/lot.131.html |title=Giovanni da Rimini: Painted Crucifix |publisher=[[Sotheby's]] |accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> Giovanni's panel paintings include what is probably half of a second diptych, ''The Virgin and Child with Five Saints'', in the Pinacoteca Comunale di Faenza ([[:it:Pinacoteca comunale di Faenza|it]]).<ref name="OUP"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://pinacotecafaenza.racine.ra.it/ita/opere/op_626.htm |title=Giovanni da Rimini, Madonna col Bambino, due Angeli e i SS. Francesco, Michele Arcangelo, Agostino, Caterina e Chiara |trans-title=Giovanni da Rimini: Madonna and Child with two angels and Saints Francis, Michael, Augustine, Catherina, and Clare |language=Italian |publisher=Pinacoteca Comunale di Faenza |accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> Also attributed to Giovanni are wall paintings in the Campanile Chapel of [[Sant'Agostino, Rimini]] ([[:it:Chiesa di Sant'Agostino (Rimini)|it]]), similarly showing Giotto's influence.<ref name="OUP"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://catalogo.fondazionezeri.unibo.it/ricerca.jsp?decorator=layout_S2&apply=true&percorso_ricerca=OA&tipo_ricerca=avanzata&mod_RSEC_OA=contiene&RSEC_OA=Giovanni+da+Rimini%20+affreschi+nella+cappella+del+campanile+in+S.+Agostino+a+Rimini&componi_OA=AND&ordine_OA=rilevanza |title=Giovanni da Rimini, affreschi nella cappella del campanile in S. Agostino a Rimini |trans-title=Giovanni da Rimini: Frescoes in the Campanile Chapel of Sant'Agostino, Rimini |language=Italian |publisher=[[Federico Zeri|Fondazione Federico Zeri]], [[University of Bologna]] |accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> Once confused with [[Giovanni Baronzio]], Giovanni da Rimini's career and the beginnings of the fourteenth-century Riminese School have been reconstructed by scholars in recent decades, beginning with the 1935 exhibition ''La pittura riminese del Trecento'', organised by [[Cesare Brandi]].<!--not Carlo Brandi, per Arts Council doc--><ref name="OUP"/><ref name="ACE">{{cite web |url=http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/media/uploads/Expert_statement_daRimini.pdf |title=RCEWA Case 4 (2014–15): Left wing of a diptych with episodes from the Lives of the Virgin and other Saints, by Giovanni da Rimini |publisher=[[Arts Council England]] |accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref>
==''Scenes from the Lives of the Virgin and other Saints''== The diptych's left wing, [[Provenance|once owned]] by the [[Barberini family]], and subsequently by Pietro and [[Vincenzo Camuccini]], was acquired as being by Giotto by [[Algernon Percy, 4th Duke of Northumberland]] in 1853, for £100. At [[Alnwick Castle]] thereafter, the painting passed by descent to the [[Ralph Percy, 12th Duke of Northumberland|12th Duke of Northumberland]], before being sold at [[Sotheby's]] in 2014 for £5.7 million, including [[buyer's premium]].<ref name="ACE"/><ref name="Sotheby's">{{cite web |url=http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/ecatalogue/2014/old-master-british-paintings-evening-l14033/lot.17.html |title=Giovanni da Rimini: Left wing of a diptych with episodes from the lives of the Virgin and other saints |publisher=[[Sotheby's]] |accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> A [[Reviewing Committee on the Export of Works of Art|temporary export bar]] was placed on the painting, on the grounds of it meeting "[[Reviewing Committee on the Export of Works of Art#Waverley Criteria|Waverley Criteria]]" 2 and 3, being of "outstanding aesthetic [[Values (heritage)|value]]" and in excellent condition, and of "outstanding significance for the study of [[Trecento]] painting in Rimini".<ref name="ACE"/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/last-chance-to-keep-rare-14th-century-italian-painting-in-the-uk |title=Last chance to keep rare 14th century Italian painting in the UK |publisher=[[Gov.uk]] |date=29 October 2014 |accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> With the financial assistance of [[Ronald Lauder]], son of [[Estée Lauder (businesswoman)|Estée Lauder]], the painting was acquired by the [[National Gallery]] in 2015, under an agreement that would see it loaned back to the benefactor for the remainder of his lifetime, with triennial displays at the Gallery, the first in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/about-us/press-and-media/saved-for-the-nation |title=Saved for the nation |date=July 2015 |publisher=[[National Gallery]] |accessdate=4 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905202126/http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/about-us/press-and-media/saved-for-the-nation |archivedate=5 September 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/jul/28/rare-painting-secured-for-uk-in-unique-deal-with-cosmetics-heir |title=Rare painting secured for UK in unique deal with cosmetics heir |author=Mark Brown |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |date=28 July 2015 |accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref>
The "jewel-like"<ref name="ACE"/> painting, showing the influence of [[Byzantine art]] and of [[Giotto]], comprises four scenes in an unusual [[iconographic]] combination that likely reflects the donor's wishes.<ref name="NG"/> Of the four scenes, the top two are of a double height, the bottom two separated by the edge of the throne in place of a decorative band. They depict, from left to right, top to bottom, the [[Apotheosis#Christianity|Apotheosis]] of [[Augustine of Hippo|Saint Augustine]], above a [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] temple standing over the saint's empty tomb, the [[Coronation of the Virgin]], above a crowd of onlooking saints and angels, [[Catherine of Alexandria|Saint Catherine]] disputing with the philosophers before Emperor [[Maxentius]], and a pairing of the episodes of [[Francis of Assisi|Saint Francis]] receiving the [[stigmata]] and [[John the Baptist|Saint John the Baptist]] in the wilderness, proclaiming the coming of the [[Messiah#Christianity|Messiah]], with a winged [[cherub]] in-between.<ref name="NG"/><ref name="ACE"/> John the Baptist's scroll reads ECCE / [[Agnus Dei (liturgy)|AGN(us) / DEI]] / ECCE / Q(u)I TO(l) / LIT (peccata mundi) ''Behold the Lambe of God, which taketh away the sinne of the world'' ([[Gospel of John|John]] 1.29, [[KJV]]).
==''Scenes from the Life of Christ''== The right wing of the diptych formed part of the Sciarra Collection until 1897 and is now in the [[Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica]], [[Palazzo Barberini]], Rome. Separated by decorative bands, the six zones of equal size depict, from left to right, top to bottom, the [[Nativity of Jesus|Nativity]], with Christ's first bath in the foreground, the [[Crucifixion of Jesus|Crucifixion]], the [[Burial of Jesus|Entombment]], the [[Harrowing of Hell|Descent into Limbo]], the [[Resurrection of Jesus|Resurrection]], with the [[The Three Marys#The three Marys at the tomb|Three Marys at the Tomb]], and the [[Last Judgment]].<ref name="Barberini"/><ref name="ACE"/>
